messages.content:
can you make a command in the terminal that echos it out so i can copy and paste all these files: After reviewing the files you've provided, I can see Cursive App is an innovative notebook application combining handwriting with AI capabilities. I'm seeing a transition toward a "Spatial Thread Model" for conversations that could significantly improve the user experience.
To create a comprehensive guide and strategic roadmap, I'd like to request these additional files:

src/types/supabase.ts - To understand your data models
src/hooks/useNotebook.ts - To understand notebook state management
src/components/canvas/TextLayer.tsx - To see the current text handling implementation
src/pages/notebooks/[id].tsx - To understand the main notebook page structure
src/contexts/AuthContext.tsx - To understand authentication flow

Sure! Here's a terminal command you can run to **echo out** the paths of all those files (e.g., to copy and paste or verify they exist):

```bash
echo "src/types/supabase.ts\nsrc/hooks/useNotebook.ts\nsrc/components/canvas/TextLayer.tsx\nsrc/pages/notebooks/[id].tsx\nsrc/contexts/AuthContext.tsx"
```

If you want to **copy all these files** into a separate folder (like for sharing or zipping), here's a command that creates a `cursive-share` folder and copies them there (adjust the `[id].tsx` path as needed):

```bash
mkdir -p cursive-share/src/{types,hooks,components/canvas,pages/notebooks,contexts} && \
cp src/types/supabase.ts cursive-share/src/types/ && \
cp src/hooks/useNotebook.ts cursive-share/src/hooks/ && \
cp src/components/canvas/TextLayer.tsx cursive-share/src/components/canvas/ && \
cp src/pages/notebooks/[id].tsx cursive-share/src/pages/notebooks/ && \
cp src/contexts/AuthContext.tsx cursive-share/src/contexts/
```

Would you also like a zipped version of the `cursive-share` folder?
i mean i want to echo the content of the file and the title both

Got it — you want a terminal command that **outputs each file's name followed by its contents**, all in one go, so you can copy and paste the full content easily.

Here’s a command that will do exactly that:

```bash
for file in \
  src/types/supabase.ts \
  src/hooks/useNotebook.ts \
  src/components/canvas/TextLayer.tsx \
  src/pages/notebooks/\[id\].tsx \
  src/contexts/AuthContext.tsx; do
  echo -e "\n===== $file =====\n"
  cat "$file"
done
```

### What it does:
- Iterates over your list of file paths.
- Echoes a clear title (`===== path/to/file.tsx =====`) before each one.
- Outputs the file contents using `cat`.

You can run this in your terminal from the root of your project folder.

Want to redirect the whole output into a single file (e.g. `all_files.txt`) instead of the screen? Add this at the end:

```bash
done > all_files.txt
```

Would you like this formatted for Markdown or HTML instead?
